key_points: The Taliban are negotiating with Qatar and Turkey regarding the management of Kabul airport.
The discussions aim to facilitate commercial flights for those wanting to leave Afghanistan.
The need for secure access to the airport was emphasized by French Foreign Minister Jean-Yves Le Drian.
The US's withdrawal has left Kabul airport without air traffic control services.
The US Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) has prohibited American civil aircraft from operating over Afghanistan without prior authorization.
Ongoing security concerns and the absence of a functional civil aviation authority in Afghanistan were cited by the FAA.
The US military temporarily took over air traffic control in Kabul during the evacuation of tens of thousands of people.
A high-altitude jet route near Afghanistan's far eastern border remains open for US civil operators with FAA authorization.
Initially, the FAA allowed US air carriers and civilian pilots to fly into Kabul for evacuation or relief flights with US Defense Department approval.
US airlines have been participating in the evacuation effort, though operating from airports outside of Afghanistan.
